awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Arecibo C3 - Center for Culturally Relevant and Inclusive Science Education, Computational Skills, and Community Engagement
awd_abstract_narration:
This award establishes a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and research center at the federally owned site in Arecibo, Puerto Rico and location of the Arecibo Observatory. Arecibo Center for Culturally Relevant and Inclusive Science Education, Computational Skills, and Community Engagement (Arecibo C3) will integrate science (ciencia), computation (computación), and community (comunidad)—geographical, disciplinary, and cultural—with the overall goal of promoting culturally-relevant and inclusive teaching with science education research, outreach, and workforce development. Arecibo C3 is a collaboration of: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras, University of Maryland Baltimore County, and Universidad del Sagrado Corazón. Arecibo C3 (a.k.a. "the Center") is purpose-built to advance STEM-equity and promote full participation in the benefits of STEM. The scholarly community of STEM education researchers will benefit from the outputs of the Center’s education research programs. STEM students, professional educators, and the public will benefit from the Center’s skill building and workforce development activities.

Arecibo C3 will serve as a collaborative hub for STEM discovery and exploration by building upon existing programs and opportunities established at the Arecibo site by previous NSF programs, while also creating new STEM education, research, and outreach programs and initiatives. The goals for the Center are to (1) promote STEM education, learning, and teaching; (2) support fundamental and applied STEM and STEM education research; (3) broaden participation in STEM; and (4) build and strengthen collaborations and partnerships. The proposed suite of experiences and research will be innovative and diverse. Research on STEM education and learning will examine the impact of multisensory teaching strategies in secondary and post-secondary education, as well as approaches for adult learning in informal contexts, ultimately contributing to increasing participation of all people –with and without disabilities– in STEM. A complementary priority will be investigating how culturally sustaining pedagogy supports student STEM identity development. Introductory research experiences for all will be offered through DNA Barcode Puerto Rico, an experience using DNA to study the biodiversity of the island. Modeled on Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory DNA Learning Center barcoding programs, collaborations with high schools and science centers across Puerto Rico will be served by new Arecibo C3 molecular and computer laboratory spaces and equipment loans. Visitor groups will also access DNA Learning Center field trips and summer courses. Visitors will also experience a multisensory course and exhibition featuring sensory experiences of data, such as the merging of black holes or behavior of bioluminescent organisms. Teachers and faculty working with experts in scientific and education research will be mentored to create, implement, and assess curricula of course-based convergent research experiences for high school and undergraduates. Arecibo C3 will create workforce development opportunities focusing on data science, computation, and biotechnology. Computational training will also reach into communities empowering women and girls in public housing with data science skills and career opportunities. Biotechnology training and credentials will tie to local industries and jobs. Arecibo C3 will feature a meetings program that convenes researchers, educators, policy makers, industry partners, and other stakeholders for think tank style conferences on pressing STEM topics. Additionally, the Center will pilot a fellowship program in which participants are trained and certified in scientific community management. Arecibo C3 Fellows will then serve as ambassadors using recently acquired collaborative strategies to involve, organize, train, support their peers in community science experiences, and build communities of practice. Ultimately, Arecibo C3 will foster equity-enabling STEM research and education, enrich Puerto Rico’s vibrant STEM communities, and serve as a catalyst for inclusive STEM education globally.

Arecibo C3 is jointly funded by the following programs at NSF: Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL), the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), Discovery Research PreK-12 (DRK-12), Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST), Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI), and the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the scope of the year 1 approved by NSF rationale of the Arecibo C3 proposal working group 1 lead by Principal Investigator Wanda L Diaz Merced says p.6.” In our proposed research, cohorts of middle school teachers (1.1) or members of the public (1.2) will be exposed to multisensorial experiments based on those developed by Díaz-Merced (LoC:16,48). As an example, participants are tasked with distinguishing between audio samples with meaningful signals or random noise. These experiments will be extended to include musical instrument samplings, and other sensory modalities such as touch using haptic devices. Students and informal learners will appreciate that scientific data can be analyzed without prior knowledge of astronomy and through a variety of senses."

 

Fully Synching with that scope and timeline for year 1 During the first year we achieved several milestones: formed coalitions with 76 special education and science teachers from the Department of Education of Puerto Rico. We also created a coalition of organizations representing people with disabilities, actively contributing to the piloting and evaluation of prototypes. We completed the design of our first multisensorial experiments (phase 1 and phase 2), including experimental design, data gathering and analysis protocols, piloting, data acquisition, and analysis.  As of November 15, 2024, we piloted 10 of these 15 experiences with special education teachers, science teachers, and people with disabilities. 

Fully Synching with the scope of the research, Work Group 1 performed perception experiments to perform a first assessment of multisensorial approaches to simulated astronomy telemetry by nonexperts.  Current literature lacks experiments assessing the effect of sound parameters on sensitivity to signals, and no perception experiments have approached it from the point of view of harmonic/inharmonic timbres, enabling sensitivities to signal detection on simulated astronomy data. As a result, two perception experiments were carried focusing independently and symmetrically on spatial orientation and timbres with diverse frequency ranges.  Testing the effect of multidimensionality on the differentiation between data sources.  We tested if these parameters would affect the sensitivity to signatures (i.e., augmenting or hindering sensitivity to signatures in the information). In Synchronicity with the original scope of the Arecibo C3 proposal for Work Package 1, the graduate student simulated astronomical information and had a cohort of 36 participants with no previous experience in astronomy information participating in the experiments.  The first perception experiment assessed was developed employing varied timbre-based synthesis. A priory result from experiment one suggests that bells-based synthesis allows for the best signal perceptibility, with horn-based synthesis allowing for better signal detection in higher noise factors, and violin-based synthesis results in the least perception of signal from the noise. The assessment suggested that violin-based synthesis with noise factor 7 is the timbre-NF (Noise-Factor) interaction parameter in which participants have performed least well. A deeper and stronger paradigm-designed inquiry of timbre-NF interactions is required to examine the effects of such correlations that allow for or hinder signal perceptibility. The participants’ population comprises 36 participants who contributed to this study.

Experiment II assessed if and whether specialization may influence signal perceptibility, the experiment design was separated into two blocks, block I, in which all four sounds were concurrently displayed in a monophonic setup. This task-orientated paradigm examined the effect of masking in spatializing four different concurrent modifications in a quadrophonic setup compared to a monophonic installation. The results of Experiment II suggest levels across trials significantly vary, suggesting that depending on variance in intensities of diverse noise channels, participants’ sensitivity to signal perception augments.

The WP1 team designed, assembled, and piloted the first prototype of the Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) RealTime light—color-sound-haptic device. The device scans images and feels the intensity and distribution of colors through sound and haptic vibration. Symmetrically, this device may be placed on the ocular of a telescope to translate into sound and haptic feedback anything on the telescope aperture. This device uses Bluetooth Low Energy Technology for those purposes.
